annotation.TEXT: Reize is the first of the wandering/optional bosses that can appear on the overworld map, and is one of five "Guest Director" enemies in this game (from what I understand, there were several prizes during the Kickstarter event for this game, one of which was for anyone who donated $1,000 or more to become the game's director for a day - thereby also implementing a special enemy of their choice/design).
Ugh...The birds. Why do all these variations of Altairs keep coming back to haunt me in these games?

The mid-boss gimmick, strangely enough, almost immediately reminded me of the Wolfduck fight from Darkwing Duck on the NES. Unlike Wolfduck however, you can actually damage this guy while he's in his monster form (killing him in said form also seems to yield better rewards compared to beating him in his human form).

Something I've seen often is that many people apparently think that Plague Knight is the most difficult boss in the game. Admittedly, it's easy to understand why. This fight is downright chaotic at times, with Plague Knight jumping, teleporting, and throwing out bombs at almost pure random (the fact that some of his moves shake the screen doesn't help matters either). Despite all this (and despite the terrible job I do at fighting him), in my opinion, Plague Knight is nowhere close to being the toughest fight in this game.
Once you trigger this scene, you'll receive the music sheet for the Dancer's song (which, for the purposes of a 100% run, is necessary to pick up).

With that out of the way, it's finally time to move on to the main event. Plague Knight's stage is aptly named the "Explodatorium." As per suggested by the level name, a good portion of the hazards involve explosions. This mainly pertains to certain enemies though, the most annoying of which are plague rats that jump when you get close to them and promptly blow up after you knock them back.

Chester will sell you the Alchemy Coin for 3,000 gold in this level. The Alchemy Coin can cause enemies to drop more gold than usual if you kill them with it (the coin can also keep going through anything it kills until it hits a wall or falls down a pit). Despite this, I find this relic's use to be somewhat limited. The coin itself is only good for hordes of minor enemies at best (it tends to bounce off things that take more than 2 hits to kill), along with the fact that it eats up quite a bit of magic per use.

Before I move on to Plague Knight's stage however, there are a few upgrades I can get in town (mostly in extending maximum magic). There's also a small scene that can be triggered here by talking with the Dancer after you beat Specter Knight, which I admittedly almost forgot to show at first.

In any case, Reize is a fair bit tougher than most of the previous bosses. His boomerangs tend to linger around on-screen for a while, which can easily get in your way as you're about to attack him. He also has a flame shield, which he'll activate as a desperation move while he's low on health.

We also get introduced to a new block-type here. Blocks that have a lighter shade of color won't cause you to bounce if you use a down-thrust on them, and will instead make you go directly through them.

Trust me, I'm not trying to put off Plague Knight's level, but these optional bonus stages aren't exactly all that common on the main map. This one takes the form of an auto-scrolling level, somewhat akin to specific stages in Super Mario Bros. 3. It doesn't last that long, but there's still a nice amount of gold and gems to grab here.

As per the results of the vote from the last segment, the next stage I'll be doing is Plague Knight (who won by a single vote, with 5 in total to his favor). Granted though, some of the comments in the previous segment were a bit vague as to whether or not they were votes, along with the fact that there was one vote for "Dig Knight" (which I assume is just a mistranslation of Mole Knight). With this in mind, Treasure and Mole Knight were both tied at 4 votes each. Given this, I'll most likely pick at random between the two for the next segment (though they'll obviously both be shown either way).
